segment.source: Manage Surface UEFI settings (Surface)
segment.target: Manage Surface UEFI settings (Surface)

segment.source: Use Surface UEFI settings to enable or disable devices or components, configure security settings, and adjust Surface device boot settings.
segment.target: Use Surface UEFI settings to enable or disable devices or components, configure security settings, and adjust Surface device boot settings.

segment.source: Manage Surface UEFI settings
segment.target: Manage Surface UEFI settings

segment.source: Current and future generations of Surface devices, including Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book, use a unique UEFI firmware engineered by Microsoft specifically for these devices.
segment.target: Current and future generations of Surface devices, including Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book, use a unique UEFI firmware engineered by Microsoft specifically for these devices.

segment.source: This firmware allows for significantly greater control of the device’s operation over firmware versions in earlier generation Surface devices, including the support for touch, mouse, and keyboard operation.
segment.target: This firmware allows for significantly greater control of the device’s operation over firmware versions in earlier generation Surface devices, including the support for touch, mouse, and keyboard operation.

segment.source: By using the Surface UEFI settings you can easily enable or disable internal devices or components, configure security to protect UEFI settings from being changed, and adjust the Surface device boot settings.
segment.target: By using the Surface UEFI settings you can easily enable or disable internal devices or components, configure security to protect UEFI settings from being changed, and adjust the Surface device boot settings.

segment.source: Note: Surface Pro 3, Surface 3, Surface Pro 2, Surface 2, Surface Pro, and Surface do not use the Surface UEFI and instead use firmware provided by third-party manufacturers, such as AMI.
segment.target: Note: Surface Pro 3, Surface 3, Surface Pro 2, Surface 2, Surface Pro, and Surface do not use the Surface UEFI and instead use firmware provided by third-party manufacturers, such as AMI.

segment.source: You can enter the Surface UEFI settings on your Surface device by pressing the Volume Up button and the Power button simultaneously.
segment.target: You can enter the Surface UEFI settings on your Surface device by pressing the Volume Up button and the Power button simultaneously.

segment.source: Hold the Volume Up button until the Surface logo is displayed, which indicates that the device has begun to boot.
segment.target: Hold the Volume Up button until the Surface logo is displayed, which indicates that the device has begun to boot.

segment.source: PC information
segment.target: PC information

segment.source: On the PC information page, detailed information about your Surface device is provided:
segment.target: On the PC information page, detailed information about your Surface device is provided:

segment.source: Model – Your Surface device’s model will be displayed here, such as Surface Book or Surface Pro 4.
segment.target: Model – Your Surface device’s model will be displayed here, such as Surface Book or Surface Pro 4.

segment.source: The exact configuration of your device is not shown, (such as processor, disk size, or memory size).
segment.target: The exact configuration of your device is not shown, (such as processor, disk size, or memory size).

segment.source: UUID – This Universally Unique Identification number is specific to your device and is used to identify the device during deployment or management.
segment.target: UUID – This Universally Unique Identification number is specific to your device and is used to identify the device during deployment or management.

segment.source: Serial Number – This number is used to identify this specific Surface device for asset tagging and support scenarios.
segment.target: Serial Number – This number is used to identify this specific Surface device for asset tagging and support scenarios.

segment.source: Asset Tag – The asset tag is assigned to the Surface device with the Asset Tag Tool.
segment.target: Asset Tag – The asset tag is assigned to the Surface device with the Asset Tag Tool.

segment.source: You will also find detailed information about the firmware of your Surface device.
segment.target: You will also find detailed information about the firmware of your Surface device.

segment.source: Surface devices have several internal components that each run different versions of firmware.
segment.target: Surface devices have several internal components that each run different versions of firmware.

segment.source: The firmware version of each of the following devices is displayed on the PC information page (as shown in Figure 1):
segment.target: The firmware version of each of the following devices is displayed on the PC information page (as shown in Figure 1):

segment.source: System UEFI
segment.target: System UEFI

segment.source: SAM Controller
segment.target: SAM Controller

segment.source: Intel Management Engine
segment.target: Intel Management Engine

segment.source: System Embedded Controller
segment.target: System Embedded Controller

segment.source: Touch Firmware
segment.target: Touch Firmware

segment.source: System information and firmware version information
segment.target: System information and firmware version information

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: System information and firmware version information
segment.target: System information and firmware version information

segment.source: You can find up-to-date information about the latest firmware version for your Surface device in the Surface Update History for your device.
segment.target: You can find up-to-date information about the latest firmware version for your Surface device in the Surface Update History for your device.

segment.source: Security
segment.target: Security

segment.source: On the Security page of Surface UEFI settings, you can set a password to protect UEFI settings.
segment.target: On the Security page of Surface UEFI settings, you can set a password to protect UEFI settings.

segment.source: This password must be entered when you boot the Surface device to UEFI.
segment.target: This password must be entered when you boot the Surface device to UEFI.

segment.source: The password can contain the following characters (as shown in Figure 2):
segment.target: The password can contain the following characters (as shown in Figure 2):

segment.source: Uppercase letters: A-Z
segment.target: Uppercase letters: A-Z

segment.source: Lowercase letters: a-z
segment.target: Lowercase letters: a-z

segment.source: Numbers: 1-0
segment.target: Numbers: 1-0

segment.source: The password must be at least 6 characters and is case sensitive.
segment.target: The password must be at least 6 characters and is case sensitive.

segment.source: Add a password to protect Surface UEFI settings
segment.target: Add a password to protect Surface UEFI settings

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: Add a password to protect Surface UEFI settings
segment.target: Add a password to protect Surface UEFI settings

segment.source: On the Security page you can also change the configuration of Secure Boot on your Surface device.
segment.target: On the Security page you can also change the configuration of Secure Boot on your Surface device.

segment.source: Secure Boot technology prevents unauthorized boot code from booting on your Surface device, which protects against bootkit and rootkit-type malware infections.
segment.target: Secure Boot technology prevents unauthorized boot code from booting on your Surface device, which protects against bootkit and rootkit-type malware infections.

segment.source: You can disable Secure Boot to allow your Surface device to boot third-party operating systems or bootable media.
segment.target: You can disable Secure Boot to allow your Surface device to boot third-party operating systems or bootable media.

segment.source: You can also configure Secure Boot to work with third-party certificates, as shown in Figure 3.
segment.target: You can also configure Secure Boot to work with third-party certificates, as shown in Figure 3.

segment.source: Read more about Secure Boot in the TechNet Library.
segment.target: Read more about Secure Boot in the TechNet Library.

segment.source: Configure Secure Boot
segment.target: Configure Secure Boot

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: Configure Secure Boot
segment.target: Configure Secure Boot

segment.source: You can also enable or disable the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) device on the Security page, as shown in Figure 4.
segment.target: You can also enable or disable the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) device on the Security page, as shown in Figure 4.

segment.source: The TPM is used to authenticate encryption for your device’s data with BitLocker.
segment.target: The TPM is used to authenticate encryption for your device’s data with BitLocker.

segment.source: Read more about BitLocker in the TechNet Library.
segment.target: Read more about BitLocker in the TechNet Library.

segment.source: Configure Surface UEFI security settings
segment.target: Configure Surface UEFI security settings

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Configure Surface UEFI security settings
segment.target: Configure Surface UEFI security settings

segment.source: Devices
segment.target: Devices

segment.source: On the Devices page you can enable or disable specific devices and components of your Surface device.
segment.target: On the Devices page you can enable or disable specific devices and components of your Surface device.

segment.source: Devices that you can enable or disable on this page include:
segment.target: Devices that you can enable or disable on this page include:

segment.source: Docking and USB Ports
segment.target: Docking and USB Ports

segment.source: MicroSD or SD Card Slot
segment.target: MicroSD or SD Card Slot

segment.source: Rear Camera
segment.target: Rear Camera

segment.source: Front Camera
segment.target: Front Camera

segment.source: Infrared (IR) Camera
segment.target: Infrared (IR) Camera

segment.source: Wi-Fi and Bluetooth
segment.target: Wi-Fi and Bluetooth

segment.source: Onboard Audio (Speakers and Microphone)
segment.target: Onboard Audio (Speakers and Microphone)

segment.source: Each device is listed with a slider button that you can move to On (enabled) or Off (disabled) position, as shown in Figure 5.
segment.target: Each device is listed with a slider button that you can move to On (enabled) or Off (disabled) position, as shown in Figure 5.

segment.source: Enable and disable specific devices
segment.target: Enable and disable specific devices

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Enable and disable specific devices
segment.target: Enable and disable specific devices

segment.source: Boot configuration
segment.target: Boot configuration

segment.source: On the Boot Configuration page, you can change the order of your boot devices and/or enable or disable boot of the following devices:
segment.target: On the Boot Configuration page, you can change the order of your boot devices and/or enable or disable boot of the following devices:

segment.source: Windows Boot Manager
segment.target: Windows Boot Manager

segment.source: USB Storage
segment.target: USB Storage

segment.source: PXE Network
segment.target: PXE Network

segment.source: Internal Storage
segment.target: Internal Storage

segment.source: You can boot from a specific device immediately, or you can swipe left on that device’s entry in the list using the touchscreen.
segment.target: You can boot from a specific device immediately, or you can swipe left on that device’s entry in the list using the touchscreen.

segment.source: You can also boot immediately to a USB device or USB Ethernet adapter when the Surface device is powered off by pressing the Volume Down button and the Power button simultaneously.
segment.target: You can also boot immediately to a USB device or USB Ethernet adapter when the Surface device is powered off by pressing the Volume Down button and the Power button simultaneously.

segment.source: For the specified boot order to take effect, you must set the Enable Alternate Boot Sequence option to On, as shown in Figure 6.
segment.target: For the specified boot order to take effect, you must set the Enable Alternate Boot Sequence option to On, as shown in Figure 6.

segment.source: Configure the boot order for your Surface device
segment.target: Configure the boot order for your Surface device

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: Configure the boot order for your Surface device
segment.target: Configure the boot order for your Surface device

segment.source: You can also turn on and off IPv6 support for PXE with the Enable IPv6 for PXE Network Boot option, for example when performing a Windows deployment using PXE where the PXE server is configured for IPv4 only.
segment.target: You can also turn on and off IPv6 support for PXE with the Enable IPv6 for PXE Network Boot option, for example when performing a Windows deployment using PXE where the PXE server is configured for IPv4 only.

segment.source: About
segment.target: About

segment.source: The About page displays regulatory information, such as compliance with FCC rules, as shown in Figure 7.
segment.target: The About page displays regulatory information, such as compliance with FCC rules, as shown in Figure 7.

segment.target: Regulatory information displayed on the About page

segment.source: Exit
segment.target: Exit

segment.source: Use the Restart Now button on the Exit page to exit UEFI settings, as shown in Figure 8.
segment.target: Use the Restart Now button on the Exit page to exit UEFI settings, as shown in Figure 8.

segment.source: Exit Surface UEFI and restart the device
segment.target: Exit Surface UEFI and restart the device

segment.source: Figure 8.
segment.target: Figure 8.

segment.source: Click Restart Now to exit Surface UEFI and restart the device
segment.target: Click Restart Now to exit Surface UEFI and restart the device
